awd_titl_txt: CICI: RSARC: Secure Time for Cyberinfrastructure Security
awd_abstract_narration:
The accurate marking and tracking of time plays a key role in scientific discovery and technology advancement. Scientific discovery is becoming increasingly reliant on more precise and reliable timekeeping. For example, the precise synchronization of time enables GPS (Global Positioning System) systems to accurately measure distances between distributed components of scientific instruments. Furthermore, tightly synchronized clocks between the base stations of mobile phone and data networks enable mobile handsets to share limited radio spectrum more efficiently. In fact, many modern critical infrastructures including computer networks, communication systems, electrical power grids, and financial networks rely on precise time and time synchronization for efficient ¬¬and safe operations. However, existing commonly used time synchronization approaches, including both GPS and the Network Time Protocol (NTP), are extremely vulnerable to attacks. As modern research cyberinfrastructure quickly evolves towards a distributed architecture with the incorporation of cloud computing resources and new forms of sensing and computing infrastructures, and as attacks on the time infrastructure have increased, developing secure time synchronization approaches for resilient time service is of paramount importance.

The focus of this project is to provide novel and holistic approaches to enable time security for cyberinfrastructures that employ the two most commonly used time synchronization mechanisms, i.e., GPS based and NTP based synchronization. More specifically, the project seeks to provide a security solution as a national service for all civil GPS time users. It will also develop and prototype a redundancy based security solution to NTP synchronization with minimal extra communication overhead. The main thrusts are to: i) establish a reference GPS receiver and server at Clemson University that can be used for GPS receivers across the US to detect spoofing attacks by cross checking encrypted military code in GPS signals; ii) develop a pulse based redundant synchronization approach to verify the reliability of network time provided by NTP; iii) experimentally prototype the two secure time approaches on a flood monitoring platform and a weather station platform, and use them to secure Clemson's campus NTP timing network in collaboration with the Information Technology (IT) department.

por.por_cntn:
The accurate tracking of time is crucial for numerous modern infrastructures including computer networks, communication systems, electrical power grids, and financial networks, among others. However, accurately tracking time in most of these systems relies on clock synchronization approaches such as GPS (the global positioning system) or network synchronization protocols (like the network time protocol-NTP), both of which have been proven to be susceptible to attacks in numerous scenarios. This project establishes a novel pulse-based time synchronization approach that is resilient against common attacks on time synchronization protocols such as data-alteration attacks and jamming attacks. The performance of the established resilient pulse-based time synchronization approach is analytically characterized under different attack scenarios, with results published in prestigious journals such as IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control and IEEE Transactions on Signal Processing. The project has also established a reinforcement learning based design approach to find the optimal pulse-based synchronization strategy that has the best resilience against attack-caused delays in communications and moderate frequency deviations of local clock frequencies. The established learning based approach is proven to be independent of network topologies and initial clock-value distributions, which allows bypassing the need for relearning the optimal resilient synchronization parameters for every new network or application scenario. The established learning based approach has been published in the prestigious journal of PNAS Nexus,  the only other research journal of the National Academy of Sciences besides PNAS. In addition to theoretical development, the project has also conducted extensive and systematic evaluations of obtained results in several practical applications. For example, using the developed resilient time synchronization approach, the project successfully achieved, for the first time, the localization of spoofing attacks on GPS receivers deployed in vehicle networks, with field-test results on real vehicles published in IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology. We have also applied/field-tested the resilient time synchronization approach on distributed weather stations for power grids and distributed flood-monitoring stations.
